questions.question_text: A security analyst is hardening a server with the directory services role installed. The analyst must ensure LDAP traffic cannot be monitored or sniffed and maintains compatibility with LDAP clients. Which of the following should the analyst implement to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Ensure port 636 is open between the clients and the servers using the communication.
choices.B: Install and configure an SSH tunnel on the LDAP server.
choices.E: Remote the LDAP directory service role from the server.
choices.C: Ensure port 389 is open between the clients and the servers using the communication.
choices.A: Generate an X.509-compliant certificate that is signed by a trusted CA.

questions.question_text: A manager suspects that an IT employee with elevated database access may be knowingly modifying financial transactions for the benefit of a competitor. Which of the following practices should the manager implement to validate the concern?

discussion.content: Shouldn't the answer be B? Separation of duties would prevent fraud but not detect it .Mandatory vacations would detect malicious activity when it occurs.
A because IT and Finance are different duties

comments.content: So they should hire a financier to manage their database? Hmmmm....

discussion.content:
The question is: Which of the following practices should the manager implement to validate the concern?
So the concern is there and now that need to validate/disprove it...

Mandatory vacations - would a lot the company time to audit his work and discover/validate the concern.
Separation of duties - would be able to prevent this from occurring in the future. 

B. Mandatory vacations
If you send the suspected insider on a vacation (implementing mandatory vacation for all employees) and the transactions stop then you will have validate the suspicions of the insider threat actor
Separation of Duties would prevent this to happend, what it's needed here is to "validate the concern", Mandatory Vacations are used to detect fraud, or suspicious activity.
It is separation of duties...IT guy with DB permissions...separation of duties would revoke his DB access and only grant to DB admins.

"knowingly modifying" key word.

A. Separation of Duties

Separation of duties -- is a means of establishing checks and balances against the possibility that critical systems or procedures can be compromised by insider threats. Separation of duties states that no one person should have too much power or responsibility. Duties and responsibilities should be divided among individuals to prevent ethical conflicts or abuse of powers. Duties such as authorization and approval and design and development should not be held by the same individual, because it would be far too easy for that individual to exploit an organization into using only specific software that contains vulnerabilities or taking on projects that would be beneficial to that individual.

comments.content:
valid point but not the question posed. Not trying to figure out how to prevent it from happening. The question only seems to be how to validate the concern that the employee is doing what they suspect him of doing... 

Which would be mandatory vacations so that employee's work could be audited. after which I'm sure they will want to implement separation of duties.

discussion.content: Lead2Pass, boasting 96% accuracy and verified by Security Professionals and charging me 100$ says "B Mandatory Vacay"...going w B!! Final Answer!!
It's def B. Seperation of duties can't necessary validate the concern. Mandatory vacations are designed to discover fraud wrongdoing etc

They need to start putting these answers together as both Seperation of duties and Mandatory Vacations helps detect fraud , this test is starting to piss me off. Comptia stop putting answers on test like this. I'm going to let them know how I feel about this on the comments section of the test.

It is possible that all this companies IT personnel may have this access, so mandatory vacations wouldn't solve this. What this problem needs is for IT to only have access to financial databases when needed, ideally 'least privilege' but also separation of duties, which would possibly allocate a DB Admin role, not accessible to all IT personnel, and only granted for specific issue resolution.

Has to be B. If he has elevated access, that won't prevent him from accessing the database even if seperation of duties occurred. If he is on vacation, then we'll know who's modifying the transactions.
This is definitely Mandatory Vacations so that the Manager can detect/ investigate on the issue.

Even if there was a separation of duties, if the IT has elevated DB access, he can always access the financial transactions no matter what. I think B is the correct answer here. Let him have a mandatory vacation and check records for validation.
I think B is correct
The thing here is validation. The manager needs to validate his concern therefore a mandatory vacation would identify the validity of the managers suspicion.

Separation of duties policies also apply to IT personnel. As an example, a group of IT administrators may be assigned responsibility for maintaining a group of database servers. However, they would not be granted access to security logs on these servers. Instead,
security administrators regularly review these logs, but these security administrators will not have access to data within the databases.
Darril Gibson CompTIA Security+ SY0-501 Study Guide
An IT employee can have db access. Also “validate the concern”. Mandatory vacations is what I would go for. Tricky question though.
Key words: Validate the concern. With separation of duties you will fix the problem but you won't know if it was real. Mandatory vacations will detect it. I think the answer is B
it said knowingly, the answer is correct.
I thought mandatory vacation too so he can be investigated, than I thought if he actually does that often than he knows what he is doing....SO A is a correct answer.
I believe the answer is A because the IT guy should not have access to the data. the duties should be separated. when access to the data is denied, the fraud will stop, thus validate the suspicions.

This question is poorly worded, since we really need to know if the IT employee SHOULD have elevated database access. If you're assuming they should, then I would put mandatory vacation as the answer. If they shouldn't have access, then the answer would be separation of duties. This seems too obvious though so I am really not sure.
He is an IT employee messing with Financial transactions.

comments.content: that doesn't prove it was them. Separate duties, the IT person shouldn't have access to the financial transactions unless they NEED to.

discussion.content: Totally B. They will have this guy go on vacation and monitor to see if the issue persists. If it does not, they'll pull him into the office on his return and surround him with lawyers and HR reps.
B mandatory vacation. thats how they will find out if the IT person is the one doing it. With he/she not being there they will she if it stops or continues.

If the DB admin was forced to take a vacation and the fraud stopped, it might be that the true fraudster was aware of the situation and would pause the fraud until the DB admin returned from vacation. DB admins sometimes have permissions to access the production database to troubleshoot immediate problems. So might be altering financial transactions in the database.
The answer is B. Mandatory Vacations are used when employees are involved in malicious activity such as fraud or embezzlement.

hear me out, B because an IT employee should not have access to the financial transactions. So separation of duties would have the same effect as mandatory vacations as well as fix the issue at the same time. Its a tricky question though.

I am not sure why the answer is A. Should be B.
"Mandatory vacation policies help detect when employees are involved in malicious activity, such as fraud or embezzlement. A mandatory vacation policy would require someone else to perform these activities, which increases the chance of discovery."
We are talking about a DB admin that voluntarily modifies records. How can the separation of duties verify this? I think mandatory vacations is the best answer...

"Mandatory vacation policies help detect when employees are involved
in malicious activity, such as fraud or embezzlement.
Mandatory vacations also provide an opportunity to discover fraud." This is straight from Daril Gibson's book. It's definetly B.

comments.content: Elevated database access is keyword, so not B, I go with A
For me "suspects" and "validate the concern" are the real keywords, they don't even know for sure that it's the IT employee committing fraud. It still seems like B is the right answer.
Database admins are also in the elevated IT employees realm. Tricky question for sure!
Why can’t an IT guy have elevated db access? Someone like an admin maybe

discussion.content:
This is tricky...
Mandatory vacations are mostly related to jobs in the financial sector, BUT also refers to dependency. When a company becomes too dependent, it becomes a problem.
Separation of duty policies are specifically designed to prevent fraud AND also elevation of one's privileges. In this case, the manager was concerned bc of the modifying of financial transactions AND the IT employee had elevated database access.

For decades, none of the big three e-mail protocols—POP, IMAP, or SMTP—had any form of encryption. Everything you did, including sending your user name and password, was in the clear. To give encryption to these protocols, the Internet folks added SSL/TLS and let your e-mail run through the encrypted tunnel, just as HTTP runs through an SSL/TLS tunnel (Mike Meyer’s CompTIA Security+ p. 430).
D. TLS or SSL for encrypting login. Only answer with SSL is D.
I thought SSL shouldn't be used anymore??
D, SSL(TLS) IMAPS

choices.D: Enable an SSL certificate for IMAP services.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester finds that a company's login credentials for the email client were being sent in clear text. Which of the following should be done to provide encrypted logins to the email server?

discussion.content:
Seems like the difference between URL hijacking and typo squatting is a subtle one.

https://www.professormesser.com/security-plus/sy0-401/url-hijacking

URL hijacking is the redirection of a user from a legitimate site to an illegitimate one. Two of the ways this can be achieved are:

- URL redirection: Redirecting users from the legitimate website to the illegitimate one. This can be done via malware, domain hijacking, domain poisoning, etc.

- Typo squatting: Sending users to a fake version of the legitimate site based on a subtle variation/misspelling of the legitimate site.

In other words, typo squatting is a specific form of URL hijacking. It's terribly confusing, I know.

As this question refers to two letters being transposed, the attack more closely aligns to typo squatting rather than URL hijacking. Hence why the answer is C.

You won't get any doubt after this:
In the case of typosquatting a user might type www.aamazon.com and think he or she is headed to the commercial giant, Amazon, but then end up at some sleazy or dangerous site.
Another method of typosquatting—also called URL hijacking—involves registering the same domain name as a legitimate company, but with a different top-level domain. For example, rather than legitcompany.com, the hijacker might register legitcompany.biz.
Mike Meyer’s CompTIA Security+ p. 438

comments.content: No they are not. Typo squatting is the best answer here.

discussion.content: url hijacking and typo squatting are the same thing
URL that was similar to the company name but with two letters transposed.

Typosquatting, also called URL hijacking, a sting site, or a fake URL, is a form of cybersquatting, and possibly brandjacking which relies on mistakes such as typos made by Internet users when inputting a website address into a web browser.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Typosquatting
Typo squatting and URL hijacking are the same and so the answer must be B

comments.content: Typosquatting occurs when the attack vector domain is very similar. URL hijacking is when a TA steals a domain that whose lease was recently expired, and uses it as a method of gaining money from the original holder of the domain.
That would be domain hijacking. According to Darril Gibson Study guide (pg 314): Typo squatting and URL hijacking are the same thing.

https://www.cisecurity.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/MS-ISAC-Typosquatting-Security-Primer.pdf
i think the keyword here is transposed. that means that two or more letters get flipped. typosquatting uses transposition in order to infect victims devices with malware. 
DNS poisoning occurs because attackers exploit the servers to send forged DNS responses that are cached as legit servers. the intent is for victims to go to these sites and download malware or submit login credentials.
https://www.globalsign.com/en/blog/what-is-dns-cache-poisoning/
since this question doesnt specifically say they went to this site and logged in, only attempted to access the URL, it makes more sense that typosquatting occured. URL hijacking and typosquatting are the same yes, but URL hijacking relates to DNS poisoning regarding the login credentials or occurs for financial gain but typosquatting/brandjacking takes advantage of misspelled words. 
this whole thing is so confusing..

questions.question_text: Before an infection was detected, several of the infected devices attempted to access a URL that was similar to the company name but with two letters transposed. Which of the following BEST describes the attack vector used to infect the devices?

discussion.content: Data Execution Prevention can prevent buffer overflow attacks so that rules out B and D. C only has a connection with the loopback address (127.0.0.1) So that only leave answer A.
DEP protects against buffer overflows and it is turned off on APACHE which also shows a remote connection.

comments.content: ...butt dialing itself. Funny funny. Let us know if you passed, huh?

discussion.content: DEP=DataExecutionPrevention...so only possible answers is HTTPd(apache) and SQL...eliminate SQL because it is butt dialing itself! Loopback Addy....APACHE FINAL ANSWER!

0.0.0.0 allows for any IP address to log in 
MySQL Local Address is set to ONLY that IP address being able to access remotely
My SQL is LoopHack and the only Option is Apache with DEP off

DEP being enabled can prevent a buffer overflow but does not eliminate them entirely. I would think the answer would be D as the local address is set to a public IP of 191.168.1.10 which is not normal. Although I'm not entirely certain on this. Perhaps someone could shed some light on why this would have a public local address?

comments.content: After review I think the IP is a typo as it's not a valid public IP either.

I'm not sure what command this came from but the format is related to some sort of routing table and specific to the process. the 0.0.0.0 Local addresses are default routes for those two processes LSASS/APACHE. 127.0.0.1 (loopback/localhost) routes only to itself. Then whatever interface 192.168.1.10 is tied to, routes outside to a remote address of 10.34.221.96. Totally valid to route a single ip to a destination. My take here is the keyword "buffer overflow". Googling DEP (Data Execution Prevention)(damage from viruses/threats), the two that are "no" are Apache and SQL. The MySql only routes to itself (localhost 127.0.0.1) so that is not it. It only leaves Apache.

discussion.content: Whay is it APACHE ? is that because of the DLP being NO ? Is DLP set to no meaning DLP did not detect a compromise or DLP is disabled ?
Is it A LSASS because of the local address being 0.0.0.0 ?
